qas.question: What process can cause beer to have a 55% abv?
What is the typical alcohol content of a pale logger?
What type of low alcohol beer is sometimes served in school?
What percentage of alcohol by volume does beer achieve when it is re-pitched with champagne yeast?
What drink ranges from 3% to 5% abv?
Where are British ales served instead of soft drinks?

context: <b7_0>Beer<b7_0/> ranges from less than 3% <a0_0><b5_0><b6_0>alcohol by volume<b6_0/><b5_0/><a0_0/> (abv) to around 14% abv, though this strength can be increased to <a4_0>around 20%<a4_0/> by <b9_0>re-pitching with champagne yeast,<b9_0/> and to 55% abv by the <a1_0>freeze-distilling<a1_0/> process. The alcohol content of beer varies by local practice or beer style. The pale lagers that most consumers are familiar with fall in the range of 4–6%, with a typical abv of <a2_0>5%<a2_0/>. The customary strength of British ales is quite low, with many session beers being around 4% abv. Some beers, such as <a3_0>table beer<a3_0/> are of such low alcohol content (1%–4%) that they are served instead of soft drinks in <b8_0>some schools<b8_0/>.
